entries.text: We're having a session of short tech talks at Thames Valley Perl Mongers, next Monday (27th March), if you fancy joining us? Topics are PDF::API2, synchronising databases, custom reports for Netdisco, packaging for Debian, and the River of CPAN.

entries.author: pat_kua
entries.text: Giving and receiving feedback can help both individuals and projects. But done wrong it can just plain suck, and when you're doing open source for fun, it can really suck. Pat shares some tips from colleagues, on giving and receiving feedback.
entries.title: The Gift of Feedback (in a Booklet)

entries.text: Friendly and quiet office in London (W1) looking for a Perl (or similar) developer with at least two years experience. You’re expected to have fullstack experience/abilities, from improvements on the client’s HTML front-end to backend services.
entries.title: Science background, or a passing interest in life sciences? Junior/mid-level Perl developer needed in London...

entries.text: he best thing — in my opinion, anyway — about working for a development team led by an active member of the London Perl community, is that you know management love Perl, support using the best available Perl tooling, and will create a technical environment where Perl developers will be happy.
entries.title: The only Perl job with a swimming pool; very exciting financial services company in London, The EU

entries.text: Varied role solving real business problems for clients, working with open source software all day - in one of the few places in the UK a house is still affordable.
entries.title: Escape London -- Mid-to-Senior Perl Developers in the Midlands (visa sponsorship possible)

header:
What's the use of being an editor of Perl Weekly,
if I can't occasionally abuse that privilege to promote my local Perl Mongers group?
Five of us are giving short tech talks next Monday (27th), if you fancy joining us.
subject: Tech talks in Reading, UK next Monday
